Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Understanding the Physics of Galaxy Clustering on Small Scales
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will measure, model, and interpret the clustering of galaxies on scales of 10 kiloparsecs to 1 megaparsec -- small scales in the cosmological context. The project consists of four main science goals. (1) Constrain the spatial distribution of galaxies inside dark matter halos in the local universe. Using redshift data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS), the proposing team will measure the projected two-point correlation function, the angular correlation function, and the surface density profile of galaxies in groups and clusters. They will model these statistics to constrain the density profile of galaxies in dark halos, using both analytic models and numerical models constructed from cosmological N-body simulations. (2) Extend the above analysis to higher redshift by using data from the new Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (BOSS). Modeling the correlation functions will reveal the recent evolution in the spatial distribution of galaxies within halos. (3) Refine the proposers' semi-analytic model for the evolution of dark matter subhalos under the influence of merging, improving the analytic prescription for mass loss and including the role of baryonic matter. (4) By comparing the improved halo model to the clustering statistics, constrain the star formation and star stripping efficiencies for galaxies merging with larger halos. The project will support the work of several graduate and undergraduate students at the two collaborating institutions. In addition, the project will provide funding for summer K-12 science camps so that minority students in the Nashville, TN area will be able to attend without financial burden.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we have studied several aspects of the clustering of galaxies on very small scales (ranging from the diameter of a single large galaxy to a scale roughly ten times larger). Our first main goal was to determine whether the spatial distribution of galaxies on these small scales differs from that of the underlying dark matter, as predicted by numerical simulations of dark matter. We measured and modeled the clustering of galaxies in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) and found that the answer to this question depends on the luminosity of the galaxies in question. Galaxies less luminous than our own Milky Way have a spatial distribution that traces that of dark matter, whereas more luminous galaxies are more centrally concentrated than dark matter. Moreover, we confirmed this result by analyzing different galaxy clustering statistics that are subject to different biases and errors. This result has interesting implications for galaxy evolution models and also calls into question widely used models that explicitly assume that galaxies trace dark matter on very small scales.

Our second main goal was to probe more physical theoretical models of galaxy evolution. We first studied the extent to which measurements of galaxy clustering contain information on the degree to which stars are stripped off of smaller satellite galaxies due to the tidal forces from their larger neighbors. We showed that galaxy clustering data can indeed constrain stellar stripping models. Moreover, we used SDSS data to discover that low luminosity satellite galaxies lose stars at a faster rate than more luminous satellite galaxies. This work is important because it uses a direct observable (galaxy clustering) to probe a physical process that is generally unobservable (tidal stripping), thus opening up a new avenue for exploring this process. We next studied a new class of simple models that connect the color and star formation rates of galaxies to the histories of the dark matter clumps that they inhabit. We found that these simple models (e.g., redder galaxies live in older dark matter clumps) are remarkably successful at predicting the different clustering of red and blue galaxies. These models have since proved very useful for modeling the distribution of galaxy properties.

The work described here has resulted in seven published papers and one in preparation and has also formed an integral part of the PhD theses of four Vanderbilt students. This grant has also attempted to address the severe problem of lack of diversity in the astronomy workforce (and in the natural sciences in general). Focusing on the K-12 level, this grant has provided logistical support for students from local underserved areas to attend summer “Space Camps” at Nashville’s Dyer Observatory.
